NVIDA graphics card MSI GT 630 2 gb

I expect the video card is to blame, as this is not really a powerful card at all. Measuring is always the best way of finding out where the problem lies. You could download GPU-Z, a measuring tool for your GPU. After downloading and installing it, you can start it up before starting your game. Also open up Windows Task Manager before starting your game. After playing for a little while you can see whether your GPU or CPU is loaded a 100%.

The best way to deal with that without buying new hardware is fiddling around with the settings. Try to find a mix of settings that look as good as possible, without bogging down your machine too much. There is often quite a lot to gain with some tweaking - just plunking a game on Medium or High often does not lead to optimal results. Personally I prefer a smooth running game to a good looking but lagging game.

Because 2.66GHz, that's why.
